instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does no input in the Economizer Maximum Limit Dewpoint Temperature field mean?
output: No input (blank) in this field means that there is no outdoor air dewpoint limit control.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be entered for the Economizer Minimum Limit Dry-Bulb Temperature field?
output: Enter the outdoor air temperature low limit (C) for economizer operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens if the outdoor air temperature is below the specified limit?
output: If the outdoor air temperature is below this limit the outdoor air flow rate will be set to the minimum and heat recovery will be enabled if available.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does no input or zero in the Economizer Minimum Limit Dry-Bulb Temperature field mean?
output: No input or zero in this field means that there is no outdoor air temperature low limit control.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be set in the Supply Plenum Name field if no supply plenum is modeled?
output: Set to blank if no supply plenum is to be modeled.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is required if a supply plenum is modeled?
output: If a supply plenum is modeled it must be modeled as a zone with surfaces and the name of the plenum zone should be entered here.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the supply plenum serve?
output: This supply plenum serves all zones on this system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens if any zone supply plenums have been specified?
output: If any zone supply plenums have been specified the outlet from the system supply plenum will flow through the zone supply plenum to the zone terminal unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be set in the Return Plenum Name field if no return plenum is modeled?
output: Set to blank if no return plenum is to be modeled.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is required if a return plenum is modeled?
output: If a return plenum is modeled it must be modeled as a zone with surfaces and the name of the plenum zone should be entered here.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the return plenum serve?
output: This return plenum serves all zones on this system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens if any zone return plenums have been specified?
output: If any zone return plenums have been specified the return air from the zone will flow through the zone return plenum and then into the system return plenum.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be entered for the Night Cycle Control field?
output: Enter the system behavior during times when the System Availability Schedule is zero (off).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the possible inputs for the Night Cycle Control field?
output: The possible inputs are 'StayOff' 'CycleOnAny' or 'CycleOnControlZone'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does 'StayOff' mean in the context of Night Cycle Control?
output: 'StayOff' means the system will remain off no matter how hot or cold the zones may be.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does 'CycleOnAny' mean in the context of Night Cycle Control?
output: 'CycleOnAny' means that if any zone served by this system has an air temperature outside the cooling or heating set points the central fan will turn on even though the System Availability Schedule indicates the fan is off.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does 'CycleOnControlZone' mean in the context of Night Cycle Control?
output: 'CycleOnControlZone' means the same thing as 'CycleOnAny' except the availability manager looks at the temperature in only the zone specified in Night Cycle Control Zone Name.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default setting for Night Cycle Control?
output: The default is 'StayOff'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be entered for the Night Cycle Control Zone Name field?
output: For the Night Cycle Control option 'CycleOnControlZone' enter the name of the control zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens to the Night Cycle Control Zone Name field for other Night Cycle Control options?
output: For other Night Cycle Control options this field is ignored.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

output: When it is autosized it is calculated from the rated capacity in kg/s and the enthalpy rise in J/kg of the feed water from a reference temperature of liquid water at 20°C to saturated steam at 100°C.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be entered in the 'Field: Return Fan Delta Pressure'?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

output: Enter the shaft power of the return fan divided by the electrical power consumed. Must be greater than 0 and less than or equal to 1. Default is 0.9.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the function of the HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object?
output: This object simulates a unitary system with option cooling coil (air-cooled DX water-cooled DX and chilled water) options heating coil (gas electric hot water air-to-air heat pump and water-to-air heat pump) with cycling or continuous fan controls.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How is the HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object typically used?
output: Often a single HVACTemplate:Zone:Unitary object will be used with a single HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object to simulate single zone system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: Can multiple HVACTemplate:Zone:Unitary objects reference the same HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object?
output: Yes multiple HVACTemplate:Zone:Unitary objects may reference the same HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object in a multiple zone version.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How is the control zone specified in a multiple zone system?
output: For a multiple zone system only one zone is specified as the control zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What types of systems can the model simulate?
output: The model can simulate chilled water or heat pump systems seen in commercial buildings and split systems commonly seen in residential buildings.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How does the HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object differ from HVACTemplate:System:Unitary and HVACTemplate:System:UnitaryHeatPump:AirToAir?
output: HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem offers more flexibility by using the more general AirLoopHVAC:UnitarySystem object instead of the more specific unitary furnace and heat pump objects.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be entered in the 'Field: Name'?
output: Enter a name for the object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object simulate?
output: This object simulates a unitary system with option cooling coil (air-cooled DX water-cooled DX and chilled water) options heating coil (gas electric hot water air-to-air heat pump and water-to-air heat pump) with cycling or continuous fan controls.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How is the HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object typically used?
output: Often a single HVACTemplate:Zone:Unitary object will be used with a single HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object to simulate a single zone system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: Can multiple HVACTemplate:Zone:Unitary objects reference the same HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object?
output: Yes multiple HVACTemplate:Zone:Unitary objects may reference the same HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object in a multiple zone version.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How is the control zone specified in a multiple zone system?
output: For a multiple zone system only one zone is specified as the control zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What types of systems can the model simulate?
output: The model can simulate chilled water or heat pump systems seen in commercial buildings and split systems commonly seen in residential buildings.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How is the HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object different from other unitary system objects?
output: HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem is similar to HVACTemplate:System:Unitary and HVACTemplate:System:UnitaryHeatPump:AirToAir but it offers more flexibility by using the more general AirLoopHVAC:UnitarySystem object instead of the more specific unitary furnace and heat pump objects.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be entered in the Field: Name for the HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object?
output: Enter a name for the HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object. This name is used in the HVACTemplate:Zone:Unitary object to reference this system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens if the Field: System Availability Schedule Name is left blank?
output: Leave this field blank if you want the system to be available for the entire year to perform heating or cooling if called for by the thermostat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be specified if a schedule name is given in the Field: System Availability Schedule Name?
output: If a schedule name is specified those times that the system is available should be specified as 1.0. Those times that the system is not available should have a zero value in the schedule specified.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What controls fan operation during times when the system is available?
output: During times when the system is available the supply fan operating mode controls fan operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the valid choices for the Field: Control Type?
output: Valid choices are Load and SetPoint.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is required for Load control in the Field: Control Type?
output: Load control requires a Controlling Zone name.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is required for SetPoint control in the Field: Control Type?
output: SetPoint control is an advanced option which requires set points at each coil outlet node. A single set point at the outlet of the system is allowed but not recommended.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What must the user add for SetPoint control in the Field: Control Type?
output: The user must add the desired setpoint managers to the idf file.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default control type in the Field: Control Type?
output: The default is Load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be entered in the Field: Control Zone or Thermostat Location Name?
output: Enter the name of the HVACTemplate:Zone:Unitary object that contains the thermostat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How many zones can contain a thermostat in a HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem system?
output: While multiple HVACTemplate:Zone:Unitary objects can be part of a HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem system only one of the zones contains a thermostat that controls heating and cooling operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be specified in the Field: Control Zone or Thermostat Location Name for a single zone system?
output: For a single zone system this field should contain the name of that zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the purpose of the HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object?
output: The HVACTemplate:System:UnitarySystem object is used in the HVACTemplate:Zone:Unitary object to reference this system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should you do if you want the system to be available for the entire year?
output: Leave the System Availability Schedule Name field blank if you want the system to be available for the entire year to perform heating or cooling if called for by the thermostat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be specified in the schedule if a schedule name is provided for system availability?
output: If a schedule name is specified those times that the system is available should be specified as 1.0 and those times that the system is not available should have a zero value in the schedule specified.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What controls fan operation during times when the system is available?
output: During times when the system is available the supply fan operating mode controls fan operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the valid choices for the Control Type field in a unitary system?
output: The valid choices for the Control Type field are Load and SetPoint.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is required for Load control in a unitary system?
output: Load control requires a Controlling Zone name.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does SetPoint control require in a unitary system?
output: SetPoint control requires set points at each coil outlet node and a single set point at the outlet of the system is allowed but not recommended.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default control type for a unitary system?
output: The default control type for a unitary system is Load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should the Control Zone or Thermostat Location Name field contain for a single zone system?
output: For a single zone system the Control Zone or Thermostat Location Name field should contain the name of that zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the Cooling Supply Air Flow Rate field specify?
output: The Cooling Supply Air Flow Rate field specifies the supply air flow rate when the cooling coil is operating.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens when you enter Autosize for the Cooling Supply Air Flow Rate?
output: By entering Autosize the supply air flow rate is automatically determined based on the loads experienced by the zone during the specified cooling SizingPeriod:DesignDay.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the units for the Cooling Supply Air Flow Rate?
output: The units for the Cooling Supply Air Flow Rate are in m3/s.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the Heating Supply Air Flow Rate field specify?
output: The Heating Supply Air Flow Rate field specifies the supply air flow rate when the heating coil is operating.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens when you enter Autosize for the Heating Supply Air Flow Rate?
output: By entering Autosize the supply air flow rate is automatically determined based on the loads experienced by the zone during the specified heating SizingPeriod:DesignDay.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the No Load Supply Air Flow Rate field specify?
output: The No Load Supply Air Flow Rate field specifies the supply air flow rate when neither cooling nor heating is required i.e. when the DX coil and heater are off but the supply air fan operates.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the condition for the No Load Supply Air Flow Rate field when the supply air fan operating mode schedule specifies continuous fan operation?
output: When the supply air fan operating mode schedule specifies continuous fan operation values must be greater than or equal to zero or this field is autosizable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What assumption does the model make if the No Load Supply Air Flow Rate is set to zero or left blank during continuous fan operation?
output: If set to zero or left blank the model assumes that the supply air flow rate when no cooling/heating is needed is equal to the supply air flow rate when the cooling or heating coil was last operating.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens when you enter Autosize for the No Load Supply Air Flow Rate?
output: By entering Autosize the supply air flow rate will be sized to match the smaller of the Cooling and Heating flow rates.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens to the supply air flow rate when the cooling coil is operating and 'Autosize' is entered?
output: The supply air flow rate is automatically determined based on the loads experienced by the zone during the specified cooling SizingPeriod:DesignDay.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: Is the flow rate multiplied by a sizing factor or by zone multipliers when Autosize is entered?
output: No the flow rate will not be multiplied by a sizing factor or by zone multipliers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What must be considered if using zone multipliers?
output: A value entered here must be large enough to serve the multiplied zones.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the units for the supply air flow rate?
output: The units are in m3/s.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default setting for the supply air flow rate?
output: The default is Autosize.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the 'Heating Supply Air Flow Rate' field specify?
output: It specifies the supply air flow rate when the heating coil is operating.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens to the supply air flow rate when 'Autosize' is entered for heating?
output: The supply air flow rate is automatically determined based on the loads experienced by the zone during the specified heating SizingPeriod:DesignDay.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the 'No Load Supply Air Flow Rate' field specify?
output: It specifies the supply air flow rate when neither cooling nor heating is required.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: When is the 'No Load Supply Air Flow Rate' field used?
output: This field is only used when the supply air fan operating mode schedule specifies continuous fan operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens if the 'No Load Supply Air Flow Rate' is set to zero or left blank?
output: The model assumes that the supply air flow rate when no cooling/heating is needed is equal to the supply air flow rate when the cooling or heating coil was last operating.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the best practice for the 'No Load Supply Air Flow Rate' when using zone multipliers?
output: It is best to autosize or leave blank.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the 'Supply Fan Operating Mode Schedule Name' field specify?
output: It specifies the name of the supply air fan operating mode schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What do schedule values of 0 denote in the 'Supply Fan Operating Mode Schedule Name' field?
output: They denote that the supply air fan and the heating or cooling coil cycle on and off together to meet the heating or cooling load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens if the 'Supply Fan Operating Mode Schedule Name' field is left blank?
output: A schedule of always zero (cycling fan) will be used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the 'Supply Fan Placement' field specify?
output: It specifies the supply fan placement type.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the two choices for supply fan placement?
output: The choices are 'DrawThrough' and 'BlowThrough'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default supply fan placement?
output: The default is 'BlowThrough'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the 'Supply Fan Total Efficiency' field specify?
output: It specifies the total efficiency of the supply fan.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How is the total efficiency of the supply fan defined?
output: It is the ratio of the power delivered to the fluid to the electrical input power.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the product of motor efficiency and impeller efficiency?
output: It is the total efficiency of the fan.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens to the value entered in the field when using zone multipliers?
output: The value entered in this field will not be multiplied by the sizing factor or by zone multipliers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the best practice when using zone multipliers?
output: It is best to autosize or leave blank when using zone multipliers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the units for the field value?
output: The units are in m3/s.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default setting for the field?
output: The default is Autosize.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the field 'Supply Fan Operating Mode Schedule Name' specify?
output: This field specifies the name of the supply air fan operating mode schedule.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How may the supply air fan operating mode vary during the simulation?
output: The supply air fan operating mode may vary based on time-of-day or with a change of season.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What do schedule values of 0 signify for the supply air fan and heating or cooling coil?
output: Schedule values of 0 denote that the supply air fan and the heating or cooling coil cycle on and off together to meet the heating or cooling load (a.k.a. AUTO fan).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What do schedule values other than 0 signify for the supply fan?
output: Schedule values other than 0 denote that the supply fan runs continuously while the heating or cooling coil cycles to meet the load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens if the 'Supply Fan Operating Mode Schedule Name' field is left blank?
output: If this field is left blank a schedule of always zero (cycling fan) will be used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the choices for the 'Supply Fan Placement' field?
output: This alpha field has two choices DrawThrough or BlowThrough.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the 'DrawThrough' option model in the 'Supply Fan Placement' field?
output: DrawThrough models a system where the supply air fan is after the cooling and heating coils and before the supplemental heating (or reheat) coil.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the 'BlowThrough' option model in the 'Supply Fan Placement' field?
output: BlowThrough models a system where the supply air fan is before all of the coils.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default setting for the 'Supply Fan Placement' field?
output: The default is BlowThrough.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the 'Supply Fan Total Efficiency' field represent?
output: This value is the overall efficiency of the fan i.e. the ratio of the power delivered to the fluid to the electrical input power.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How is the total efficiency of the supply fan calculated?
output: It is the product of the motor efficiency and the impeller efficiency.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How is motor efficiency defined?
output: The motor efficiency is the power delivered to the shaft divided by the electrical power input to the motor.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How is impeller efficiency defined?
output: The impeller efficiency is power delivered to the fluid (air) divided by the shaft power.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How is the power delivered to the fluid calculated?
output: The power delivered to the fluid is the mass flow rate of the air multiplied by the pressure rise divided by the air density.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the acceptable range for the 'Supply Fan Total Efficiency' value?
output: This input value must be between 0 and 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default value for 'Supply Fan Total Efficiency'?
output: The default is 0.7.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the 'Supply Fan Delta Pressure' field specify?
output: Enter the pressure rise in Pa at full flow and standard conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are considered standard conditions for 'Supply Fan Delta Pressure'?
output: Standard conditions are considered 20 C at sea level 101325 Pa.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default value for 'Supply Fan Delta Pressure'?
output: The default is 600 Pa.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the 'Supply Fan Motor Efficiency' field represent?
output: Enter the shaft power of the supply fan divided by the electrical power consumed.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the acceptable range for 'Supply Fan Motor Efficiency'?
output: Must be greater or equal to the Supply Fan Total Efficiency and less than or equal to 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default value for 'Supply Fan Motor Efficiency'?
output: The default is 0.9.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the 'Supply Fan Motor in Air Stream Fraction' field specify?
output: Enter the fraction of the motor heat that is added to the air stream.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does a value of 0 indicate in the 'Supply Fan Motor in Air Stream Fraction' field?
output: A value of 0 means that the motor is completely outside the air stream.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does a value of 1 indicate in the 'Supply Fan Motor in Air Stream Fraction' field?
output: A value of 1 means that all of the motor heat will go into the air stream and act to cause a temperature rise.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the acceptable range for 'Supply Fan Motor in Air Stream Fraction'?
output: Must be between 0 and 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default value for 'Supply Fan Motor in Air Stream Fraction'?
output: The default is 1.0.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the available types for the 'Cooling Coil Type' field?
output: There are seven coil types available: SingleSpeedDX (the default) TwoSpeedDX MultiSpeedDX TwoStageDX TwoStageHumidityControlDX HeatExchangerAssistedDX SingleSpeedDXWaterCooled ChilledWater ChilledWaterDetailedFlatModel HeatExchangerAssistedChilledWater None.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: Which object does the 'SingleSpeedDX' coil type use?
output: SingleSpeedDX uses the Coil:Cooling:DX:SingleSpeed object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: Which object does the 'TwoSpeedDX' coil type use?
output: TwoSpeedDX uses the Coil:Cooling:DX:TwoSpeed object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: Which object does the 'MultiSpeedDX' coil type use?
output: MultiSpeedDX uses the Coil:Cooling:DX:MultiSpeed object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

output: Standard conditions are considered 20 C at sea level 101325 Pa.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does a value of 0 mean for the Supply Fan Motor in Air Stream Fraction?
output: A value of 0 means that the motor is completely outside the air stream.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

output: A value of 1 means that all of the motor heat will go into the air stream and act to cause a temperature rise.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the required range for the Supply Fan Motor in Air Stream Fraction?
output: Must be between 0 and 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

output: This field defines the number of cooling speeds if a multi-speed cooling coil is specified.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: When does the 'Number of Speeds for Cooling' field apply?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is usually set for the 'Cooling Coil Availability Schedule Name' field?
output: Usually set to blank which allows the cooling coil to be available anytime the system is operating.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does a schedule name specify for the 'Cooling Coil Availability Schedule Name' field?
output: If a schedule name is specified it defines when the coil is available.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: When is the 'Cooling Coil Availability Schedule Name' field most often used?
output: This is most often used when cooling is only available seasonally.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does a schedule value of 1.0 indicate for the cooling coil?
output: A schedule value of 1.0 indicates that the cooling coil can be on during a given time period.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does a schedule value of zero denote for the cooling coil?
output: A value of zero denotes that the cooling coil cannot be used during that time period.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What temperature should be entered for the 'Cooling Design Supply Air Temperature' field?
output: Enter the cooling supply air temperature in °C to be used for sizing the cooling coil and zone supply air flow rates.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default cooling design supply air temperature?
output: The default is 12.8°C.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be entered for the 'DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated Total Capacity' field?
output: Enter Autosize to let the automatic sizing algorithm determine the cooling coil gross total cooling capacity based on the maximum cooling loads during the cooling design day. If a value is entered it represents the full load gross total cooling capacity including both sensible and latent capacity in watts of the DX coil unit at rated conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the rated conditions for the DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated Total Capacity?
output: Rated conditions are air entering the cooling coil at the maximum supply air flow rate at 26.7°C drybulb/19.4°C wetbulb with air entering the outdoor air-cooled condenser coil at 35°C drybulb.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does 'gross' capacity mean in the context of the DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated Total Capacity?
output: Capacity should be the 'gross' i.e. the effect of supply air fan heat is not accounted for.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the units for the DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated Total Capacity?
output: The units are in W.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default setting for the DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated Total Capacity?
output: The default is Autosize.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: When is the DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated Total Capacity field used?
output: This field is only used when the cooling coil type is set to one of the DX options.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the assumed low-speed capacity for two-speed DX coils?
output: For two-speed DX coils the low-speed capacity is assumed to be 0.33 times this value.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the assumed stage 1 capacity for two-stage DX coils?
output: For two-stage DX coils the stage 1 capacity is assumed to be 0.5 times this value.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be entered for the 'DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated Sensible Heat Ratio' field?
output: Enter Autosize to allow the sizing algorithm to determine the sensible heat ratio based on the gross rated cooling total capacity and air flow rate. Otherwise enter the value of the ratio of the gross sensible capacity divided by gross total cooling capacity of the DX cooling coil at rated conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does 'gross' mean in the context of the DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated Sensible Heat Ratio?
output: Both the sensible and total cooling capacities used to define the Rated Sensible Heat Ratio (SHR) should be 'gross' i.e. the effect of supply air fan heat is not accounted for.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: When is the DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated Sensible Heat Ratio field used?
output: This field is only used when the cooling coil type is set to one of the DX options.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default setting for the DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated Sensible Heat Ratio?
output: The default is Autosize.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default cooling supply air temperature for sizing the cooling coil and zone supply air flow rates?
output: The default cooling supply air temperature is 12.8°C.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be entered to let the automatic sizing algorithm determine the cooling coil gross total cooling capacity?
output: Enter 'Autosize' to let the automatic sizing algorithm determine the cooling coil gross total cooling capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does the entered value represent if not using Autosize for the cooling coil gross total cooling capacity?
output: It represents the full load gross total cooling capacity including both sensible and latent capacity in watts of the DX coil unit at rated conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the rated conditions for the cooling coil gross total cooling capacity?
output: Rated conditions are air entering the cooling coil at the maximum supply air flow rate at 26.7°C drybulb/19.4°C wetbulb with air entering the outdoor air-cooled condenser coil at 35°C drybulb.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default value for the cooling coil gross total cooling capacity when the cooling coil type is set to one of the DX options?
output: The default is Autosize.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is assumed for two-speed DX coils regarding low-speed capacity?
output: For two-speed DX coils the low-speed capacity is assumed to be 0.33 times the gross rated total capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is assumed for two-stage DX coils regarding stage 1 capacity?
output: For two-stage DX coils the stage 1 capacity is assumed to be 0.5 times the gross rated total capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What should be entered to allow the sizing algorithm to determine the sensible heat ratio?
output: Enter 'Autosize' to allow the sizing algorithm to determine the sensible heat ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the rated conditions for air-cooled DX coils?
output: For air-cooled DX coils the rated conditions are air entering the cooling coil at the maximum supply air flow rate at 26.7°C drybulb/19.4°C wetbulb with air entering the outdoor air-cooled condenser coil at 35°C drybulb.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the rated conditions for water-cooled DX coils?
output: For water-cooled DX coils the rated conditions are 26.7°C (80°F) entering air dry-bulb temperature 19.4°C (67°F) entering air wet-bulb temperature and 29.4°C (85°F) entering water temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is assumed for two-speed DX coils regarding low-speed SHR?
output: For two-speed DX coils the low-speed SHR is assumed to be equal to the gross rated sensible heat ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is assumed for two-stage DX coils regarding stage 1 SHR?
output: For two-stage DX coils the stage 1 SHR is assumed to be equal to the gross rated sensible heat ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is assumed for two-stage DX coils with humidity control regarding the humidity control mode SHR?
output: For two-stage DX coil with humidity control the humidity control mode SHR is assumed to be 0.9 times the gross rated sensible heat ratio (for both stage 1 and stage 2).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How is the coefficient of performance (COP) for DX cooling coil defined?
output: The coefficient of performance is defined as the gross cooling coil total capacity in watts divided by electrical power input in watts of the DX cooling coil unit at rated conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default COP for the DX cooling coil?
output: The default COP for the DX cooling coil is 3.0.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is assumed for two-speed DX coils regarding low-speed COP?
output: For two-speed DX coils the low-speed COP is assumed to be 1.5 times the gross rated COP.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is assumed for two-stage DX coils regarding stage 1 COP?
output: For two-stage DX coils the stage 1 COP is assumed to be the gross rated COP.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is assumed for two-stage DX coils with humidity control regarding the humidity control mode COP?
output: For two-stage DX coil with humidity control the humidity control mode COP is assumed to be 0.9 times the gross rated COP (for both stage 1 and stage 2).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: Where is the heating coil located in the supply air stream?
output: The heating coil is located in the supply air stream downstream of the cooling coil.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the choices for the heating coil type?
output: The choices for the heating coil type are Electric Gas HotWater SingleSpeedDXHeatPumpAirSource (air-to-air heat pump) and MultiSpeedDXHeatPumpAirSource (air-to-air heat pump).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the rated conditions for water-cooled DX coils?
output: The rated conditions for water-cooled DX coils are 26.7°C (80°F) entering air dry-bulb temperature 19.4°C (67°F) entering air wet-bulb temperature and 29.4°C (85°F) entering water temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is assumed about the low-speed SHR for two-speed DX coils?
output: For two-speed DX coils the low-speed SHR is assumed to be equal to the rated value.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the assumption for stage 1 SHR in two-stage DX coils?
output: For two-stage DX coils the stage 1 SHR is assumed to be equal to the rated value.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the SHR assumption for two-stage DX coil with humidity control?
output: For two-stage DX coil with humidity control the humidity control mode SHR is assumed to be 0.9 times the rated value for both stage 1 and stage 2.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How is the coefficient of performance (COP) for the DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated COP defined?
output: The coefficient of performance (COP) is defined as the gross cooling coil total capacity in watts divided by electrical power input in watts of the DX cooling coil unit at rated conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the rated conditions for the DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated COP?
output: Rated conditions are air entering the cooling coil at the maximum supply air flow rate at 26.7°C drybulb/19.4°C wetbulb with air entering the outdoor air-cooled condenser coil at 35°C drybulb.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is included in the input power for the DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated COP?
output: The input power includes electric power for the compressor and condenser fan but does not include the power consumption of the supply air fan.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default value for the DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated COP?
output: The default value for the DX Cooling Coil Gross Rated COP is 3.0.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the assumption for low-speed COP in two-speed DX coils?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the assumption for stage 1 COP in two-stage DX coils?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What are the options for the Economizer Type field?
output: The options for this field are FixedDryBulb DifferentialDryBulb FixedEnthalpy DifferentialEnthalpy ElectronicEnthalpy FixedDewPointAndDryBulb DifferentialDryBulbAndEnthalpy NoEconomizer.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does choosing NoEconomizer mean?
output: Choosing NoEconomizer means the economizer will not operate and the outdoor airflow rate will be at the minimum for the entire simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens when FixedDryBulb is chosen?
output: Choosing FixedDryBulb means the economizer will set the outdoor airflow rate at minimum if the outdoor air temperature is higher than a specified dry-bulb temperature limit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does DifferentialDryBulb do?
output: Choosing DifferentialDryBulb will trigger the outdoor airflow to minimum when the dry-bulb temperature of outdoor air is higher than the dry-bulb temperature of the return air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How does FixedEnthalpy operate?
output: FixedEnthalpy checks the upper limit of the enthalpy given as a field input against the enthalpy content of outdoor air and will set the outdoor airflow rate to minimum if the latter is greater than the former.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the function of DifferentialEnthalpy?
output: DifferentialEnthalpy compares the return air enthalpy with the enthalpy of outdoor air setting the outdoor air flow rate to minimum when the enthalpy of outdoor air is greater.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the role of ElectronicEnthalpy?
output: Choosing ElectronicEnthalpy enables the simulation to calculate the humidity ratio limit of outdoor air based on the dry-bulb temperature of outdoor air and a quadratic/cubic curve and compare it to the actual outdoor air humidity ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens if the actual outdoor humidity ratio is greater than the calculated humidity ratio limit in ElectronicEnthalpy?
output: If the actual outdoor humidity ratio is greater than the calculated humidity ratio limit then the outdoor airflow rate is set to minimum.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does FixedDewPointAndDryBulb compare?
output: FixedDewPointAndDryBulb compares both the outdoor dewpoint temperature and the outdoor dry-bulb temperature to their specified high limit values.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens if either outdoor temperature exceeds the high limit value in FixedDewPointAndDryBulb?
output: If either outdoor temperature exceeds the high limit value the outdoor airflow rate is set to minimum.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the function of DifferentialDryBulbAndEnthalpy?
output: DifferentialDryBulbAndEnthalpy enables the control strategy to be based on both the DifferentialDryBulb and DifferentialEnthalpy economizer control strategies.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What happens when 'NoEconomizer' is chosen?
output: Choosing 'NoEconomizer' means the economizer will not operate and the outdoor airflow rate will be at the minimum for the entire simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does choosing 'FixedDryBulb' mean?
output: Choosing 'FixedDryBulb' means the economizer will set the outdoor airflow rate at minimum if the outdoor air temperature is higher than a specified dry-bulb temperature limit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What triggers the outdoor airflow to minimum when 'DifferentialDryBulb' is chosen?
output: Choosing 'DifferentialDryBulb' will trigger the outdoor airflow to minimum when the dry-bulb temperature of outdoor air is higher than the dry-bulb temperature of the return air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How does 'FixedEnthalpy' control the outdoor airflow rate?
output: 'FixedEnthalpy' checks the upper limit of the enthalpy given as a field input against the enthalpy content of outdoor air and will set the outdoor airflow rate to minimum if the latter is greater than the former.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does 'DifferentialEnthalpy' compare?
output: 'DifferentialEnthalpy' compares the return air enthalpy with the enthalpy of outdoor air and sets the outdoor air flow rate to minimum when the enthalpy of outdoor air is greater than the enthalpy of the return air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the function of 'ElectronicEnthalpy' in economizer control?
output: Choosing 'ElectronicEnthalpy' enables the simulation to calculate the humidity ratio limit of outdoor air based on the dry-bulb temperature of outdoor air and a quadratic/cubic curve and compare it to the actual outdoor air humidity ratio. If the actual outdoor humidity ratio is greater than the calculated humidity ratio limit then the outdoor airflow rate is set to minimum.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What does choosing 'FixedDewPointAndDryBulb' involve?
output: Choosing 'FixedDewPointAndDryBulb' compares both the outdoor dewpoint temperature and the outdoor dry-bulb temperature to their specified high limit values. If either outdoor temperature exceeds the high limit value the outdoor airflow rate is set to minimum.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: How does 'DifferentialDryBulbAndEnthalpy' control strategy work?
output: 'DifferentialDryBulbAndEnthalpy' enables the control strategy to be based on both the 'DifferentialDryBulb' and 'DifferentialEnthalpy' economizer control strategies.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What upper limits are checked by each economizer control type?
output: In addition to all economizer control types listed above each control type checks for user-entered values for the upper limit of dry-bulb temperature enthalpy limit humidity ratio limit and dewpoint limit. The outdoor air flow rate is set to minimum if any of these entered limits are exceeded.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
input: What is the default control type for the economizer?
output: The default for this field is 'NoEconomizer'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: HVAC Template Objects -> Section: Group -- HVAC Templates -> text
